text: Always aim for less/high ROI when starting, I think its $3 for you although you can go lower with the place/cancel/replace trick if done on a small scale

elements.text: Always aim for less/high ROI when starting, I think its $3 for you although you can go lower with the place/cancel/replace trick if done on a small scale

text:
As <@U4H19D1D2> suggests, the general consensus is to start off with a bigger margin and then slowly work down to find the optimal profit per bet/ROI threshold. However...the downside is that if you want to then analyse your real-world bet logs, you won't have any data for the lower ROI bets. So you could argue that it's better to start with lots of bets with an EV >= 0 and then filter out the 'bad' ones when you have enough data.
Like all investments, you have to decide what your lowest threshold is for ROI, i.e. if bank A is offering 5% interest but £1000 maximum deposit and bank B is offering 4% with a £2000 limit, which one is 'better'?

text: I'll be that guy who says it depends. Generally I prefer strategies that let me make more (uncorrelated) bets - it means more trials, I realize my EV faster, my Sharpe is higher. And another thing to consider: higher margin strategies means you may be going for more competitive bets, leading to potentially higher adverse selection if your execution is poor etc.

text:
Ok so reflecting on your posts, thanks for the input everyone.

> filter out the 'bad' ones when you have enough data
I thought for sure this would be committing the cardinal sin of 'backfitting' - retrospectively selecting only the good bets. Does this have any predictive value?

Actually, this is what's tying me up at the moment. My strategy for discovering how to implement my model involves adjusting the parameters of execution such that the resulting backtest profit is optimised. I feel like this is breaking some kind of statistical rule of thumb?

E.g. scientifically, you propose a hypothesis - 'laying at odds of 2 at t-10 will produce the highest EV'. The backtest shows a marginal profit, then you adjust to t-9, t-8 etc to squeeze the most EV out, moving away from the original hypothesis you chose. Is that acceptable?
